body: The biggest problem with Vim for right-to-left languages like Persian(Farsi), Arabic, Hebrew and Urdu is that Vim doesn't support them! :( Please add some bidi to #Neovim and save us!

Well, there is no such thing in Vim implemented, as it is mentioned in :help rl too. Let me explain about it a little. It is all about showing and editing content, and not saving it. In english all characters flow from left to right, so this is simple to handle. In a pure Farsi text, all characters are shown from right to left, and Vim can handle this too using :set rl. The problem comes from the time that we want to mix Farsi with english, like when we are developing a Farsi HTML page. in that case currently in Vim all Farsi characters are shown from left to right which is wrong. Pure English should be like: ⇨⇨⇨⇨⇨english content⇨⇨⇨⇨⇨ Pure Farsi: ⇦⇦⇦⇦⇦متن فارسی⇦⇦⇦⇦⇦ Farsi and English mixed together should be like: ⇨⇨⇨english content⇨⇨⇦⇦متن فارسی⇦⇦⇦⇨⇨english content⇨⇨⇨ Using Vim regularly will act like: ⇨⇨⇨english content⇨⇨⇨⇨ی‌س‌ر‌ا‌ف‌ ن‌ت‌م⇨⇨⇨⇨⇨english content⇨⇨⇨ Using :set rl will act like: ⇦⇦⇦tnetnoc hsilgne⇦⇦⇦⇦متن فارسی⇦⇦⇦⇦⇦⇦tnetnoc hsilgne⇦⇦⇦ Its a shame that enemy, #emacs has solved this problem!

@Jookia It cannot be only burden of the GUI since there are such things as `virtcol()` and bar motion. I.e. in

```
⇨⇨⇨english content⇨⇨⇦⇦متن فارسی⇦⇦⇦⇨⇨english content⇨⇨⇨
```

`ی` (first symbol in the displayed string, last farsi string in byte stream) should be reported as being on virtual column 23. To do so `virtcol` implementation must know which display cell farsi symbol occupies in GUI.

I do not think moving through paragraphs will be affected at all, but inline motions like `h`, `f`, `t`, `w` are different. I do not write in farsi so cannot say what will be convenient for writers, but I think it would be consistent if displayed direction is kept: `h` from “english content” will move to first displayed farsi character, not to the next character in byte stream, `f` and `t` will also find first displayed farsi character. The relevant part regarding [[neo]vim](https://terminal-wg.pages.freedesktop.org/bidi/prior-work/applications.html#vim-neovim):

> They don’t do BiDi, however, do Arabic shaping. This combination really doesn’t make sense to me.

> Even worse, they run the shaping algorithm on the reverse (LTR) order. I think shaping only does the right thing with `set rl`, the full paragraph kinda implies they didn't try that. Maybe `arabicshape` should be effectively disabled when `set norl`, if it is broken then. It would simplify the code also (only need to deal with shaping in the rl branches).

Just an update - was recently implemented in libvte by @egmontkob: https://terminal-wg.pages.freedesktop.org/bidi/implementations.html#vte

So it is possible to start testing right now, if build VTE following aforementioned recommendations.

@XVilka what concretely is the functionality you think nvim should start using? I think nvim should use "explicit mode" as recommended here https://terminal-wg.pages.freedesktop.org/bidi/recommendation/basic-modes.html as nvim needs to be "aware" and control layout itself. But what is different from what nvim does today? should nvim enter some local "explicit RTL" mode while drawing a `set rl` window, so that text will be selected/copied in the right direction?

@bfredl, yes I agree about the explicit mode, it makes sense for all text-editing applications, in fact. See also https://terminal-wg.pages.freedesktop.org/bidi/future-improvement-ideas/explicit-level2.html
The tricky part would be cursor positioning, line wrapping, splitting the window, etc.

> if build VTE following aforementioned recommendations.

I should update that page; vte has switched to the meson build system since I wrote those bits. See vte's README.md for details.

NVim (and any sophisticated app which does its own BiDi) should do the following. (I should add a new section to the document about this.)

- Switch to "Explicit" mode, and back to "Implicit" when quitting.

- Decide whether it wishes to always use "Explicit LTR", or in some cases "Explicit RTL".

  - Always using "Explicit LTR" is the safe bet, this is the legacy behavior that every terminal emulator supports.

    In this case the "designed correct" behavior is that you switch to "LTR" at startup, and to the "default direction" when quitting. In practice, currently in VTE these two are the same (I'm not sure about MinTTY, the other terminal that implemented BiDi according to the new proposal), but in a couple of years VTE might also introduce an "RTL is the default" behavior and then it'll make a difference.

    Also note that some terminals (e.g. Linux console, urxvt) have a faulty parser and perform side effects on these escape sequences. It's a philosophical question whether to push them to fixing these bugs, or to play safe and avoid hitting these issues.

  - "Explicit RTL" offers better copy-pasting experience (the order of letters, as well as excluding the spaces after (= to the left of) the end of a line), better search functionality in the terminal – these kinds of subtle things.

    In this case you need to switch to "RTL" at startup, and back to the "default direction" on exit. It's up to you whether you wish to disable "keyboard arrow swapping" or not; if you disable then you should re-enable when you quit.

    "Explicit RTL" should only be enabled if a terminal that supports this feature is detected/assumed, via magic (e.g. checking $VTE_VERSION >= 5703) or a config option.

  - It's possible to use a mixture of "Explicit LTR" and "Explicit RTL" on a per-line basis. E.g. "Explicit RTL" for the document area if an RTL text file is loaded, and "Explicit LTR" for the status/command line if the overall UI language is English. Or the other way around. It's not possible to go with such mixture with partial lines (in case of vertical split), though.

    In this case you need to switch between "LTR" and "RTL" as you paint the screen, and back to "default direction" when you quit. You also need to disable "keyboard arrow swapping" (otherwise you can't tell the key for certain without a race condition) and re-enable it on exit.

    Again, only do this is the terminal is known to support "Explicit RTL" mode.

In my BiDi document I somewhat incorrectly claimed that (Neo)Vim don't do BiDi, but do Arabic shaping on the incorrect order of the letters. This has also been quoted here in this thread. I now know that there's a `set rl` which I haven't tried yet. Anyway, about shaping:

The currently released v0.1 of the proposal says that shaping needs to be done by Vim et al, using Presentation Form Characters. Based on the feedback I received on the Unicode mailing list, this is going to change for v0.2 (I'll update it as soon as I have time to work on this), and VTE already behaves according to this forthcoming standard.

According to forthcoming BiDi spec v0.2, and VTE's current behavior, Vim and friends should emit the "regular" unshaped codepoints (U+06xx and such), shaping is done by the terminal emulator.

> It's possible to use a mixture of "Explicit LTR" and "Explicit RTL" on a per-line basis. E.g. "Explicit RTL" for the document area if an RTL text file is loaded, and "Explicit LTR" for the status/command line if the overall UI language is English. Or the other way around. It's not possible to go with such mixture with partial lines (in case of vertical split), though.

How should nvim move cursor and draw in this mode? will column 0 represent the right end of the line in this mode, and outputting chars will move the cursor to the left (while still increasing the column number)? Then it sounds like (when terminal support is detected) we should not do "set rl" internally in nvim's screen buffer (we just keep the text logically in increasing column order), and the terminal will reverse these lines for us.

> According to forthcoming BiDi spec v0.2, and VTE's current behavior, Vim and friends should emit the "regular" unshaped codepoints (U+06xx and such), shaping is done by the terminal emulator.

So I think `arabicshape` should be off by default when nvim is in `norl` (left-right) mode, and also when using "explicit RTL". Only when nvim does `set rl` on a window internally should `arabicshape` be used.

> will column 0 represent the right end of the line in this mode, and outputting chars will move the cursor to the left (while still increasing the column number)?

Yes. The emulation *logic* is not affected, but everything's *displayed* in reverse order: column 0 is at the right, etc. Also note that mirrorable glyphs (e.g. parentheses) are mirrored.

I'm not familiar with (n)vim's internals at all; in fact, I'm not really familiar with (n)vim as a user either. So I cannot give an advice whether "explicit RTL" is something you should be using or not.

Nevertheless, here's my recommendation for the near future; focusing on the most important thing (the order of letters):

Start by adding the expicit/implicit switch as soon as possible.

You can test that with old vs. new VTE that the current neovim behavior is different in these two. A config option that fixes Hebrew text rendering in one breaks it in the other, and vice versa (or breaks in both :)). This is not something you want to offer to your users and document. By toggling explicit/implicit mode on startup/exit you should no longer see such differences, VTE's behavior while using neovim should remain the same as it was with older VTE versions (regarding the order of letters; shaping is a different story).

This could be followed by refinements for shaping, e.g. altering the default of a corresponding setting. Note that VTE currently replaces the letters by their corresponding Presentation Form Characters internally, and if neovim does this instead (assuming that it does correctly) then it's probably harmless. However, VTE's rendering might be improved one day to an even more beautiful one (or another terminal emulator might implement BiDi with nicer rendering than the presentation form chars), thus using the regular codepoints is recommended.

Once these quick fixes are done, there's no need to hurry experimenting with "explicit RTL" and evaluating whether nvim wishes to use that mode or not.

Note, that with the release of [GNOME 3.34](https://www.gnome.org/news/2019/09/gnome-3-34-released/) the support of BiDi by @egmontkob is available in Gnome Terminal out of the box, which makes testing/implementing it in the other programs, such as NeoVim way easier.
Is there any update on this?

This opens the possibility to CVE-2021-42574 (Unicode right-to-left override attack) which is a more sophisticated RLO attack and requires very careful mitigations. Any implementation should clarify with a thread model how to prevent this [rather old attack technique](https://krebsonsecurity.com/2011/09/right-to-left-override-aids-email-attacks/).

From [krebsonsecurity](https://krebsonsecurity.com/2021/11/trojan-source-bug-threatens-the-security-of-all-code/comment-page-1/)
```txt
Here’s the problem: Most programming languages let you put these Bidi overrides in comments and strings. This is bad
because most programming languages allow comments within which all text — including control characters — is ignored by
compilers and interpreters. Also, it’s bad because most programming languages allow string literals that may contain
arbitrary characters, including control characters.
```

The interesting take on this is that editors should be the obvious choice to detect this, because their job is to visualize the different meanings of the utf8.

I don't think editors are the obvious choice to detect CVE-2021-42574. The intent of supporting BiDi text is to enable working with text that incorporates multiple languages as "seamlessly" as possible. It's not clear to me what an editor could do to indicate suspicious usage of those text markers. This is particularly difficult because the problems in the CVE are somewhat tied to language semantics. For instance, Rust's mitigation denies certain BiDi control codepoints within comments and within string literals. So any sort of mitigation would probably have to be tied into the syntax highlighting system, which would need to be enhanced for each syntax to treat certain uses of these characters as errors.

> It's not clear to me what an editor could do to indicate suspicious usage of those text markers.

You need to check, if relative order of words + word types matches against what the editor shows on disabling RLO (the current setting). Most likely by invoking treesitter 2 times and querying every object of one parse against the other parse.
@matu3ba I'm actually not sure I understand what you're proposing. Of course BiDi markers change the order in which words appear, reading left to right.

> Of course BiDi markers change the order in which words appear, reading left to right.

1. Bidi must only appear in string variables and comments (and may only modify a full string or comment.)
2. Bidi must never modify other lexems, statements or any bigger structure like function, non-primitive/compositional variables etc.

Now the question is: Does switching reading from left to right in mid change any of the 2 assertions?
For checking one needs to compare a file with bidi disabled and a file with bidi enabled in its structural information (a parse),
because getting structural information requires a parser.
From my point and with the only tool aviable that scales (treesitter) this requires copying the file (to tmp or mmap into memory) and reparse with bidi symbols removed.

A conservative approach checks what segments of a file are changed due to bidi and checks the 2 parses against another, if
all stuff except string variable definitions and comments has an identical order.
For string variable definitions or comments a "all or nothing" would also be good.

Is this more clear now?

I think Neovim should expose an API to change the direction of only a given line number. That would be a useful start. I had a bidi plugin idea but couldn't do it because of this feature missing

My idea was simple:
- listen to text insertion and deletion events
- pipe the current line into fribidi
- replace the current line with fribidi's output (making sure that the cursor is still in the same position)
- iterate through the current line's characters till an RTL or LTR character is encountered and change the line's direction accordingly

I have looked at this before through this Neovide future request, https://github.com/neovide/neovide/issues/1991, and now l looked at it again.

I think the support could be added in steps, just to get stated somewhere. The first step could be to be able to correctly render a file containing bidi, and when pasting or inserting such text through the API. 

It doesn't seem like something that Neovide can do by itself at the moment; when rendering bidi the whole paragraph has to be considered, and the UI protocol only sees what's visible on the screen. So, just like the TUI, GUIs also need some processing to be done by Neovim, or a completely new UI protocol, where the whole paragraph is available. Just sending the data about the direction is also not enough, since the shaper is missing the information from outside the screen, and will therefore render incorrectly in some cases. 

So, therfore converting to the presentation form using something like freebidi, before sending the data through the UI protoocol is probably the best option that covers both TUI and GUIs. That's basically the explicit mode level 1 in https://terminal-wg.pages.freedesktop.org/bidi/.

Level 2 seems much more complex and needs new protocols, and the main advantage is to be able to use the terminal or GUI copying. But since Neovim has it's own yank support, that's probably not as important. Note that this kind of information could be useful for other purposes as well, like to be able to use custom or even variable fonts, but alone it's still not enough, so there's no need to start this way.

Late to the party here.
Looking specifically at Hebrew - but this is most likely relevant for Persian, Urdu, etc.
Some workarounds + caveats:
1. NeoVim has `:set rl` command - it moves line numbers and replaces the word order - problem is it does so for both English and Hebrew words. This is workable if you are using Hebrew / English exclusive documents. Combining both languages is not pretty.
2. Using a terminal that supports Bidi (like `mlterm`) is better, and you get a [pretty good result](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0c4050fb-aca1-48ba-84dd-3f0788f74fc9) but marks like ! are still not aligned correctly, and most importantly text is aligned to the left. Don't try `:set rl` because [it will flip both Hebrew and English](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0364dfc7-aa0c-4f6e-b011-34350c6bebf2).
3. There's a cool [Bidi plugin](https://github.com/mcookly/bidi.nvim) for nvim that runs on `BidiEnable rl` command, however I could not get it to work correctly for both English and Hebrew ([alacritty](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/658a19b9-c97c-4e3e-8879-10dd5f7cc3fc) | [mlterm](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/07d787ce-a1a3-4b6f-8437-14b6d84f3c4d)).
4. Best result I got was from [neatvi](https://github.com/aligrudi/neatvi) - vim clone that supports Bidi. This does nothing in [alacritty](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a24aa85a-e818-4a99-b558-4445137d5d53), but with [mlterm](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d24ac03c-ea6e-4914-99e6-db5cf9cc40ac) you get the complete package: 1) Automatic rtl / ltr based on beginning of the line - no need to run commands. 2) English and Hebrew work in the same line. 3) No reversed text at all. 4) Copy paste with `yy` & `pp` works correctly for English and Hebrew.

**TLDR; If you really need a workaround, use  `mlterm` with NeoVim. Use [neatvi](https://github.com/aligrudi/neatvi) with `mlterm` for best results.**

However, Emacs proves you can get Bidi right regardless of terminal support. I think the best solution would be to edit the NeoVim source code, beginning by providing automatic rtl / ltr orientation. Again, this already exists with `:set rl` but we need to make this automatic. If we can get that, combine it with `mlterm` and you almost have full support. Later we can add Bidi support for terminals that don't have it out of the box (which is almost all of them, it seems).
What about `:set termbidi` (or `lua vim.o.termbidi = true`), does it work?
